original_data.question: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for sleeping problems and the inability to concentrate for 3 months. She says she is worried because she and her husband have been trying to conceive for more than a year with no success. Conception by in vitro fertilization was attempted once 3 months ago but was unsuccessful. Analysis of her husband's semen has shown normal sperm counts and morphology. She has a 6-year-old daughter who was born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She has no history of severe illness and tries to stay healthy by going to the gym an hour per day. Her menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 to 6 days; her last menstrual period started 2 days ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's inability to conceive?

model_response:
This patient's history suggests primary ovarian insufficiency (POI), also known as premature ovarian failure (POF). The definition of POI is based on the presence of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism with ovarian failure before the age of 40 years. The diagnosis is suggested by amenorrhea in a woman less than 40 years of age with evidence of ovarian failure. The diagnosis can be confirmed by finding elevated serum FSH and LH levels and low serum estradiol levels. The incidence of POI is about 1% in women 15 to 20 years of age and increases to 7% in women 25 to 30 years of age. The risk of POI is increased in women with a history of ovarian surgery, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy. The risk is also increased in women with a history of autoimmune disease, such as lupus, and in women with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. The risk is also increased in women with a history of galactosemia. The risk is decreased in women with a history of smoking. The risk of POI is increased in women with a family history of POI. The diagnosis of POI is suggested by the history of infertility and the inability to conceive despite the presence of a patent fallopian tube as evidenced by the patient's previous pregnancy. The diagnosis is confirmed by the finding of elevated serum FSH and LH levels and low serum estradiol levels. The finding of a 46, XX karyotype rules out Turner syndrome, which is another cause of infertility. The finding of a 46, XY karyotype rules out Klinefelter syndrome, which is another cause of infertility. The finding of a 46, XY/46, XX mosaic karyotype also can cause infertility. The finding of a 46, XY/47, XXY karyotype suggests the diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome. The finding of a 46, XY/45, XO karyotype suggests the diagnosis of Turner syndrome. The finding of a 46, XY/47, XYY karyotype suggests the diagnosis of XYY syndrome.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a common cause of infertility. However, the patient's history does not suggest PID. She has no history of dyspareunia, no history of irregular menstrual cycles, and no history of pelvic pain. The physical examination also is normal. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is another cause of infertility. However, the patient's history does not suggest this diagnosis. She has no history of amenorrhea, no history of delayed puberty, and no history of short stature. Her physical examination also is normal. Premature ovarian failure (POF) is another cause of infertility. The patient's history suggests POF. She has a 6-year-old daughter who was born after an uncomplicated pregnancy. This suggests normal ovarian function until at least 35 years of age. The patient's physical examination is normal, and she has no history of amenorrhea. The finding of a 46, XX karyotype rules out Turner syndrome, which is another cause of infertility. The finding of a 46, XY karyotype rules out Klinefelter syndrome, which is another cause of infertility. The finding of a 46, XY/46, XX mosaic karyotype also can cause infertility. The finding of a 46, XY/47, XXY karyotype suggests the diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome. The finding of a 46, XY/45, XO karyotype suggests the diagnosis of Turner syndrome. The finding of a 46, XY/47, XYY karyotype suggests the diagnosis of XYY syndrome.

Diminished ovarian reserve is another cause of infertility. However, the patient's history does not suggest this diagnosis. She has no history of amenorrhea, no history of delayed puberty, and no history of short

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.

Conditions characterized by disturbances of usual sleep patterns or behaviors. SLEEP WAKE DISORDERS may be divided into three major categories: DYSSOMNIAS (i.e. disorders characterized by insomnia or hypersomnia), PARASOMNIAS (abnormal sleep behaviors), and SLEEP WAKE DISORDERS secondary to medical or psychiatric disorders. (From Thorpy, Sleep Disorders Medicine, 1994, p187)
Inadequate personal response to problems or difficulties
A solution or suspension composed of active and/or inert ingredient(s) with increased strength in a reduced volume, which is usually diluted prior to administration.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Mental distress resulting from concern for something impending or anticipated.
A male partner in marriage.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Fertilization of an ovum by a spermatozoon resulting in formation of a viable zygote.
An assisted reproductive technique that includes the direct handling and manipulation of oocytes and sperm to achieve fertilization in vitro.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A male partner in marriage.

The encapsulated embryos of flowering plants. They are used as is or for animal feed because of the high content of concentrated nutrients like starches, proteins, and fats. Rapeseed, cottonseed, and sunflower seed are also produced for the oils (fats) they yield.

Mature male germ cells derived from SPERMATIDS. As spermatids move toward the lumen of the SEMINIFEROUS TUBULES, they undergo extensive structural changes including the loss of cytoplasm, condensation of CHROMATIN into the SPERM HEAD, formation of the ACROSOME cap, the SPERM MIDPIECE and the SPERM TAIL that provides motility.
form and structure of an organism or one of its parts.
A female human offspring.
The event of being born.
Birth at greater than or equal to 37 weeks using best estimated due date.
Record and study of past events.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
A state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.
Having no significant health-related issues.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
Occurring or done each day.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
A time period, or other type of interval, during which something may be achieved, obtained or observed.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
Inadequate personal response to problems or difficulties
The capacity to conceive or to induce conception. It may refer to either the male or female.
